docs.snippet: LAWRENCE-William Goadby, 88. A world renowned artist, died in Edgecomb, Maine on January 5, 2002. He was the youngest son of Robert Cutting Lawrence and Marguerite Lowe Lawrence. Bill's paintings are in the permanent collections of the Library of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE-William Goadby, 88. A world renowned artist, died in Edgecomb, Maine on January 5, 2002. He was the youngest son of Robert Cutting Lawrence and Marguerite Lowe Lawrence. Bill's paintings are in the permanent collections of the Library of Congress, the Museum of Natural History, and the U.S. Coast Guard Academy Museum. He served in the United States Coast Guard in World War II and was awarded the Silver Star for Gallantry and Intrepidity in Action. Bill is survived by his wife of 42 years, Nathalie Brown Lawrence, his nephews, H. Lloyd Lawrence, Jr., Robert C. Lawrence, III, and nieces Genevieve L. Condos, Marguerite L. Lawrence, Grace L. Harding, Margo L. LaBau and Camilla Smith. Memorial contributions may be made to the Miles Health Care Center, Bristol Road, Damariscotta, ME 04543.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  Lawrence, William Goadby

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your March 11 Political Memo predicts that the emerging economic recovery will hurt the Democrats and help the Republicans in the Congressional elections this November. This assumes that most Americans base their voting decisions...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your March 11 Political Memo predicts that the emerging economic recovery will hurt the Democrats and help the Republicans in the Congressional elections this November. This assumes that most Americans base their voting decisions on only one or two issues.
docs.abstract: Wendy R Sheldon letter on March 12 article suggests voters will pay close attention to wide range of issues, not just economic recovery

headline.main: Why We Vote as We Do

docs.snippet: Responding for the first time to a nuclear policy report by the Pentagon, North Korea today denounced proposed revisions of United States  military strategy as ''an inhuman plan to spark a global nuclear arms race'' and warned of ''strong counterm...
docs.lead_paragraph: Responding for the first time to a nuclear policy report by the Pentagon, North Korea today denounced proposed revisions of United States military strategy as ''an inhuman plan to spark a global nuclear arms race'' and warned of ''strong countermeasures'' against the plan. In one of its toughest attacks on the United States, North Korea said it could ''not remain a passive onlooker'' after its inclusion among the countries cited by the Pentagon as potential targets.
docs.abstract: North Korea says Pentagon's proposed revisions of United States military strategy could spark global nuclear arms race; denounces policy and warns of 'strong countermeasures'; says it cannot remain passive onlooker in face of Pentagon recommendation for new nuclear weapons tailored to strike at targets in North Korea, among others; North Korean attack, one of its toughest, appears intended to play on fears that it does have ability to fire missiles carrying nuclear warheads or biological and chemical weapons (M)

headline.main: North Korea Denounces U.S. Nuclear Plan, Promises 'Response'

docs.snippet: The colorful dress of 1960's flower children, hippies and Vietnam War protesters reappeared on some of last Saturday's protesters, who marched from Fifth Avenue and Central Park to the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, site of the World Economic Forum. Some ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The colorful dress of 1960's flower children, hippies and Vietnam War protesters reappeared on some of last Saturday's protesters, who marched from Fifth Avenue and Central Park to the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, site of the World Economic Forum. Some members of the forum recalled their own participation in the 60's protests, but they were on the inside now, looking out at the moving rainbow of antique clothing, fringe, feathers, platform shoes, communist-style army coats and people in flags. This carnival look began with the first Easter Sunday be-in, in 1967 in the Sheep Meadow. While last week's participants were demonstrating their real-world concerns, many by coincidence had slipcovered themselves in the old anti-establishment style.
docs.abstract: Photos of sevrral 1960's flower-child and hippie-inspired outfits seen in New York City (On the Street column) (M)

docs.snippet: SINDEBAND-Seymour Jay. The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science of Columbia University expresses its sorrow at the loss of its counselor, benefactor, and friend, Seymour Jay Sindeband. After receiving his A.B., B.S., and M.S. de...
docs.lead_paragraph: SINDEBAND-Seymour Jay. The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science of Columbia University expresses its sorrow at the loss of its counselor, benefactor, and friend, Seymour Jay Sindeband. After receiving his A.B., B.S., and M.S. degrees from Columbia, and serving as a Naval officer during World War II, Mr. Sindeband pioneered computer applications that included systems for airlines, banks, railroads, and the American Stock Exchange. At Columbia he served on the Advisory Council of the Engineering School, and in a rare honor, received both the John Jay Award and, like his father, the Egleston Medal. The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science extends deepest sympathy to the Sindeband family. Zvi Galil, Dean, The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science, Columbia University

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDEBAND, SEYMOUR JAY

docs.snippet: Ben Perkins Jr. saddled the winner of Aqueduct's Fred Capossela Stakes for the third year in a row and fourth time over all when Spin Zone won by three lengths yesterday.     Spin Zone was ahead of the field wire to wire in the $79,650 race, follo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ben Perkins Jr. saddled the winner of Aqueduct's Fred Capossela Stakes for the third year in a row and fourth time over all when Spin Zone won by three lengths yesterday. Spin Zone was ahead of the field wire to wire in the $79,650 race, followed by President Butler. War Native was 5.75 lengths back in third.
docs.abstract: Spin Zone wins Fred Capossela Stakes at Aqueduct (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a Jan. 3 news article, you quote Richard T. Foltin of the American Jewish Committee as saying a 10-point statement issued by the American Civil Liberties Union and other groups soon after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks did not recognize the need to protect the national security.
docs.abstract: Letter by Anthony D Romero of ACLU says multi-group statement signed by ACLU after Sept 11 clearly stated government's obligation to protect nation from further attacks(S)

docs.snippet: KALOSH-Anne M., MD on March 16, 2002. Born in Milwaukee, WI; graduated Marquette University Nursing 1941. Served as a U.S. Army nurse from 1942 thru 1946 in the European Theatre; first wave of nurses landing at Normandy, Battle of the Bulge, etc. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: KALOSH-Anne M., MD on March 16, 2002. Born in Milwaukee, WI; graduated Marquette University Nursing 1941. Served as a U.S. Army nurse from 1942 thru 1946 in the European Theatre; first wave of nurses landing at Normandy, Battle of the Bulge, etc. Awarded numerous decorations and citations. After War, attended Medical College of Wisconsin, graduating in 1955. Completed her residency in OB-GYN at St. Vincent's Hospital, NYC, and was an attending physician there for almost 40 years. Also enjoyed working at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in NYC. Beloved sister of the late Dr. Frances Kalosh DiTolla, Peter, and Michael Kalosh. Loving aunt of Dr. and Mrs. William DiTolla, Dr. and Mrs. James DiTolla, Mr. John and Robyn DiTolla, Dr. Mary DiTolla and her husband William Zeh, Brenda, Michael, Mary Anne, Anne Frances, and Mark Kalosh.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALOSH, ANNE M., MD
